body: There is also exactly the same issue with `list_zones` so `iterate_zones` should be implemented in a same fashion as well.

Are those instances already available? IIRC, they were announced during re:invent, but they haven't been officially available / launched yet.

If they are, `INSTANCE_TYPES` and `REGION_DETAILS` dicts in `libcloud.compute.ec2` should be updated as well.

Ah, nice catch there! Yes I just received the E-mail from AWS this morning stating there availability in all regions with the exception of GovCloud (US) and South America (SÃ£o Paulo). I'll go ahead and update the dictionaries momentarily.
Sounds good, thanks.

Looks good.

I've squashed the commits and merged the changes into trunk. This pull request can be closed now.

Thanks!
Patch merged into trunk, thanks!

@thanatos Can you please close this pull request?

(we (committers) don't have access to do that)
@alex can you please close this pr?
Let me know if this is more in the vein of what you'd like buddy.

Ugh, sorry, looks like I've missed one thing in my previous review.

For consistency with other drivers, can you please also rename the methods from "destroy" to "delete" (`ex_destroy_security_group` -> `ex_delete_security_group`, ...) ?

Besides that, the patch looks good.

While merging and testing the patch, I have noticed a test failure under Python 2.5. I have forgot that `enumerate` function in 2.5 doesn't support `start` argument.

I've fixed that, squashed the commits and merged patch into trunk.

Thanks!
Ah, nice catch on that. I try to stay consistent, but I clearly missed that one. I've updated for your review!

Thanks!

While reviewing and merging the patch, I've noticed that you forgot to update `ex_delete_security_group` method and the tests didn't detect that because they had a typo in the name so they didn't actually run (`text` instead of `test`).

I've squashed your commits, fixed those two issues in 4df8dd2781d986f702adfd1392b569cad86a2b8e & adba6dee07066cb9ad745af37d98c7a564aba23c and merged your patch into trunk.

When I find some more time, I'll also have a look at how we can automatically detect and prevent issues like this from happening in the feature. It seems that for a start, we could do a simple integration with coverage.py and make sure that all the newly added test cases are actually executed.
Ah, that's what I get for updating code with egg nog in hand. Thanks for catching that!

I went ahead and made the requested changes. To inherit from Node I also had to set the name argument to None as reserved instances do not have names or tags where we can pull the Name key/value pair.
I've gone ahead and made changes to these calls to more closely resemble ex_list_networks. The subnet information is now stored inside of an object.

Thanks!

The PR looks mostly good, but I've made some minor changes after merging the patch:
1. I've modified `EC2ReservedNode` constructor to call parent constructor - 49e2f3bf55b9ef510e48c8c7174d7377f27e620a
2. I've removed unused arguments from the `EC2ReservedNode` constructor method - 49e2f3bf55b9ef510e48c8c7174d7377f27e620a
3. I've also passed `size` attribute to the `EC2ReservedNode` constructor. We can do this because `list_sizes` call is cheap (it doesn't result in HTTP request since sizes are stored locally in the module). - 11abec495e0125cf037e468b2dbed70d5254a055
4. I've moved test from `NimbusTests` to `EC2Tests` class since this functionality is EC2 specific. I imagine you just looked for `list_nodes` tests and you accidentally put `list_reserved_nodes` test above it. - 1655e850a71cca1af35ece6f795aa44fa5029958
5. I've renamed `list_reserved_nodes` method to `ex_list_reserved_nodes`. Sorry if I've confused you with "you can drop the ex prefix from the class name" comment. We still use `ex_` prefix, but only for method and argument names.
Sorry for the late response, totally forgot about this... See my comments above.
Ah, thanks for that and good call on the list_sizes.
@roadhead No problem, I've replied to your comments.

@cderamus Hey, I've noticed you closed the PR. I assume this is intentional? :)

And happy holidays to you as well :)

Yup there was an issue that I corrected shortly thereafter and I also assumed that you wouldn't want a PR with all of the other commits from prior issues/PRs. If that isn't a problem and is okay then I'll just re-open it now and you can review it at your convenience. 

What are you doing reading this on Christmas anyways? You should be relaxing!

@cderamus I went ahead, made the "ex_delete_network" change mentioned above and merged changes into trunk.

I had some issues (conflicts) with applying the patch and squashing the commits so I just went ahead and directly merged your branch into trunk.

Can you please synchronize this branch with the latest trunk?

I've also noticed you merged other branches into this one. This might cause problems / merge conflicts when I will try to merge this patch into trunk.

Yeah, that's correct - PR should be based directly off trunk and self-sustaining.

Merging pull requests can sometimes be relaxing. And I should ask you the same thing :)

Yeah I actually was a little over-zealous this week creating a dozen or so branches for all of these different issues and mucked things up a bit on my end. I'm going to close this and I'll create a new branch in my fork to ensure only these changes are included and hopefully also mitigated issues on your end. After this change and LIBCLOUD-471 I'll try to stagger the updates a bit more so I'm not hitting you with a dozen all at once :).

I did the same thing as in the other branch (modified ex_delete_subnet to take an instance instead of an id) and merged the patch into trunk.

Thanks!
Also forgot to add - this time it worked better. There were no merge conflicts and I could apply the patch cleanly.
Excellent news. Hopefully that is a tradition that continues!
Good to go!

I've made two changes and merged patch into trunk:
1. Removed obsolete comment from the docstring and clarified which keys the returned dictionary contains. The docstring you have provided didn't help much because you would still need to check the code to see which keys the dictionary contains.
2. Fixed test failure on Python 3.3. `base64.b64decode` returns `bytes` in Python 3 and you need to call `.decode` on it to get a string back.
Great, thanks!
@Kami: Ah, wasn't aware of that. :-) Closing!

Assuming that you're okay with these changes I will create a new branch later today to convert all extra_attributes_map dictionaries from type -> cast_func to remain consistent and also will set up the new utility function that we previously discussed. Thanks!
I went ahead and added the raise condition into ex_associate_address_with_node so it gets thrown should the user use that method or the deprecated ex_associate_address method.

@cderamus Yeah, sounds good.

I've squashed the commits, updated the docstring and merged patch into trunk. Thanks!

Thanks.

The patch looks good so I've merged in into trunk. I just made one little change (hope you don't mind).

I've renamed `cast_func` to `transform_func`. After giving it some more thought, I think `transform_func` is a better name because the function "transforms" the value.
Works for me!

I really like the idea. It is something I was also thinking a lot in the past and I think it's a step in the right direction.

To put the whole thing into perspective for the other people who might view this pull request. This pull request aims to solve a problem with the "dynamic" nature of Python which makes it hard to enforce interfaces and other things. All of this causes inconsistent API and confusing to the user.

Currently, most of this stuff is enforced manually (during code reviews) which obviously doesn't scale and it's prone to errors.

```
<off topic>
Waiting for someone to come here and troll and say we should re-write the whole thing in a statically typed language with a better support for interfaces :P
</off topic>
```

Now some high-level comments about the whole thing:
1. I think this tool should have a concept of rules (or whatever we end up calling it), similar to pep8, pyflakes, pylint and other lint tools. You have already described a couple of good rules in the description.
2. Fixing existing violations will probably be quite painful and take a while. I think a good start would be to make this tool solid and enable and strictly enforce it for all the new contributions.
3. Yes, I hate drivers and methods which (ab)use kwargs. It's an ugly artifact from the first releases which should be fixed.
4. How should we call this thing? It's not really a linter. libcloud-interface-enforcer or something? :)

I also plan to add some more comments about the implementation later on.
My reading of this is that `only_allocated` shows addresses that are allocated, but not associated. Have I misunderstood? If not, would `only_associated` be a better name?

Also I wonder if allocation_id should be encapsulated within an ElasticIP class, so instead of passing elastic_ip_address AND allocation_id, you pass a single object. 

(This PR has caused me to look at the various elastic IP API's we have for other providers - bright box, cloudstack, openstack, haven't looked further yet - and i'm going to try and propose a 'standard' API for the feature. Hiding allocation_id would be needed to do that).
Yes, only associated would likely be a better name for this and certainly comes with less ambiguity.

Given that virtually all cloud vendors have some form of public/floating/elastic IP addresses I am all for creating a standard API for this with a class (eg: NodeAddress). I do wish Amazon wouldn't require the allocation ID for VPC related actions as it would certainly make this a bit easier.

It would also be good to update a fixture which is used with `list_volume_snapshots` test case to include a tag with a key `Name` and update a test case to assert that the name is parsed out correctly.
You got it. I'll update that now.

I also forgot to add that I would like to see this thing up and running for new contributions asap.

This means that a very simple script should do. We can then extend and make it more generic, robust, etc. later on. I think this would also be a great task for GSoC 2014.
Merged into trunk, thanks!
@Kami I think I addressed all of your feedback.  Please take a look and let me know if you have other feedback or suggestions.  Also, let me know if you have any thoughts on the list_snapshots thing.

Merged into trunk, thanks!

I would also appreciate if going forward, you could write a bit more descriptive commit messages. This means you should at the minimum include what have you changed / added / removed and in which driver.

As you have probably noticed, I reword most of the commits while merging the patch, so it's not a big of a deal, but if you could do it, it would save me some time and I could preserve the original commit message which would be ideal :)
Not a problem Tomaz and thanks for the assist.

The patch is pretty big, but I think it mostly looks good.

Only thing I would ask you is if you could re-organize the methods a bit - this means moving "private" (methods prefixed with an underscore) after the "public" method to the bottom (https://libcloud.readthedocs.org/en/latest/development.html#function-and-method-ordering).

This will make the code and Sphinx documentation generated from the docstrings a bit easier to read and follow.
I promise to squash commits next time, sorry about that :).

@Kami I reordered the methods in gce.py, and made that minor change to nodelist.

Also, I went ahead and added list_volume_snapshots.  It turns out it wasn't too hard to filter by the volume they were created from.  If the volume is deleted, the volume reference is removed from the snapshot, but that shouldn't affect list_volume_snapshots negatively.

Great, thanks for working on this!

Changes have been merged into trunk.

Can you please sync your branch with the latest trunk and squash the commits? After you do this, I will go ahead and merge the patch.

Hm, the pull request looks really messed up now.

I've tried manually checking out your branch and squashing the commits, but I also encountered conflicts. To save both of us some time & pain, I will make an exception this time and directly merge your branch into trunk.

@Kami Currently the API documentation requires being logged in. The old url will continue to work, however as it is being phased out we are submitting the patch and will make an announcement once it is ready so that it can be included.
@Kami Currently the API documentation requires being logged in.

@diablob OK, sounds good.

I didn't know you work for HostVirtual. Usually, if patch comes from a 3rd party person I like to verify it against documentation or some other reference.

I've merged patch into trunk.

There were some lint issues which I have fixed. Next time make sure you run `tox -e lint` and fix any outstanding lint issues.

Thanks!

@Kami . Thanks! I suspect those lint issues were from my vim environment. I thought it already checked for pep8 too. suggest any good vim plugin ? 

I'll remember to run tox.

I use a `python_flake8` vim plugin (https://github.com/nvie/vim-flake8) which runs flake8 on a Python file every time it's saved.

It worth nothing that this plugin uses default flake8 setting and for libcloud we use slightly less restrictive settings (we allow longer lines in the test files). This means that the plugin might sometimes report violations while `tox -e lint` won't report any.
Also, this pull request can be closed now.
This pull request can be closed now.

@Kami , thanks, I moved from python_flake8 to syntastic ( https://github.com/scrooloose/syntastic ) recently and didn't realize I had to enable it in .vimrc as let g:syntastic_python_checker = 'pylint'. Hope this will solve the issue.

Closing this pull request and thanks again for merging it
Thanks!

@cderamus Sorry for the delay.

For now, I would leave this as it is (`ex_destroy_image`). The reason for that is that there are some other drivers which also use this name. On top of that, renaming the method also breaks backward compatibility. Or if we decide to add a wrapper for the old method, this means we now need to support two methods until we fully deprecate it. None of this is ideal.

I know there is some confusion and no clear guidelines on when to use destroy and when to use delete. Most of the old APIs use destroy (e.g. `destroy_node`) and the new ones use delete.

I will try to find some time in the near future and publish some clear guidelines on the method naming.

Ah okay, my mistake for not going through the other drivers to validate that before proposing the change. 

No worries about the guidelines, it was only about five minutes of work :). Cheers.

I went ahead fixed the failing tests and made the `look_for_keys` and `allow_agent` change described above and merged this patch into trunk.

Thanks!

Just checking in to see what direction you guys would like to go to support this functionality. If @Jc2k is indeed going to propose promoting this to the base API then I'll go ahead and close this out.
@cderamus If a standard API promotion is going to take a while, I'm OK with merging this into trunk if you can update the code to use `ElasticIP` class as suggested by @Jc2k.
+1. Hope to look at core API soon, but having this merged suits me.

@cderamus Also, I don't want to rush you, but the whole 0.14.0 release has already been taking longer than usual and I would like to start a voting thread for it soon and it would be great if we could include this change in it.
@Kami I live for pressure! I'm planning on dedicating a few hours to the project this evening and will bump this to the top of my list. I should have no issues getting this shored up.
@cderamus heh, great! :)

Sorry about the bad commit message on this one guys. I went ahead and added a new ElasticIp class into the driver and put all VPC specific attributes into the extra dict. As I was making the change I couldn't help but think that the all_properties boolean is sort of silly now that we're using a class.
I'll be submitting a follow-up with some additional changes momentarily.

@Jc2k I believe this is what you wanted. Leveraging the ElasticIp instance required a new keyword argument 'domain' which is only used for VPC actions. If anything other than vpc is passed in the class will throw. Thanks for the suggestions as this was definitely a better approach.
+1 for IP

One other note on this PR is that I removed the groups parameter in _to_nodes and now build the security groups list using _get_security_groups. This seemed like a cleaner implementation given that security groups also need to be built for network interfaces as well.

@cderamus Yep, I noticed that and I like this approach more.

Thanks!

I'm going to add more comments, but for testing that the token is present you should add a test case to the `MockHttp` class which actually receives the requests and returns the mock responses.

For example, you could set MockHttp.type inside `test_token` method and then add a corresponding method to the MockHttp class and verify that token is present in the headers.

E.g. 

``` python
 def _TOKEN(self, method, url, body, headers):
    self.assertEqual(headers['x-amz-security-token'], ...)
   ...
```

The headers passed in there don't seem to contain any auth-related parameters.

``` python
(Pdb) headers
{'Host': 's3.amazonaws.com', 'Accept-Encoding': 'gzip,deflate', 'User-Agent': 'libcloud/0.14.0-beta3 (Amazon S3 (standard)) '}
```
